sourceDesc.p: Created from original research by members of CWRC/CSÉC unless otherwise noted.

div.head: Replace with your title.
div.p: [SPAINE.][SPain] beeing greater then [France], & leſſer then [Germanie], is environed with the great [Ocean] and the [Mediterranean] ſea, except on the north-eaſt ſyde, for there it is cononeat with [France], from the which it is deuyded by by the monmaines called the [Pireates], it is now one entire monarchie but in former ryme hath bene denyded into fourtęene Kingdomes. By authors thus recounted vid. The old and new [Caſhlia], [Lean], [Arragea], [Catalonia], [Nanarre], [Aſluria], [Granada], [Valentia], [Taledo], [Galicia], [Murcia], [Cordona], [Portagal], & [Algarbe].[Spaine] albeit it bee not in all places manured becauſe of the ſtonyeſſe of fundry parres thereof, yet is it far more fertil then [Africa], & in very many places it yeildeth aboundantly whatſoever is neceſſary for the vſe of man, As very faire [VVheirs], [Rice], [VVyne], [Qyle], [Henry], [Saſſran], [Sugar], [Linnus], [Capers], [Cirrons], [Orenges], [Pomgranades], & other fruytes. [Raſmary] groweth there in the fieldes in ſuch plenty that it ſerueth for fuel. It hath alſo great ſhore of beaſtes both wild & tame, & yeildeth horſes of ſuch ſwiftnes that it was ſaid of them in old tyme (as a prouerb) that they were engendred of the wynde.It hath alſo diuers mynes, as of [Gold], [Siluer], [Copper], [Tin], [Iron], and [Lead], & gold is not only found in mynes, but euen in ſaud on the ſydes of the nuevr [Taye]. In fundry maritime places it yeildeth great ſhore of [Salt]. The ayre is pure and helthful, it is little ſnhieƈt vnto tempeſtes, & is free from foule & contagious miſtes. According to a vulgar ſaying three thinges in Spaine are for the rarety of them very memorable, to wit, A bridge ouer the which water runneth, which vſually runneth vnder bridges, enrending therebythe aquaduƈt of [Segouia]. A towneeńuyroned with fyre, meaning [Madrid], the walles whereof are of flint. And a bridge whereon ten thowſand beaſtes are continually paſtured, which is venderſtood by the riuer [Guaɖuana], which running into the earth hydeth it ſelf the length of ſeauen leagues, & then coming footh againe holɖeth his courſe as before.
